 With an excerpt:
 Moon-based lasers could uncover exotic physics
 14:55 25 June 2007
 NewScientist.com news service
 David Shiga
 
 Enlarge image
 A reflector left on the Moon as part of the Apollo 14 mission consists of many closely spaced reflecting prisms arranged in a grid (Image: NASA)
 
 NASA is funding the development of lasers that could be placed on the Moon to check for subtle deviations from the standard theory of gravity.
 
 Lasers have been used to make very precise measurements of the Earth-Moon distance since the Apollo era, when astronauts left reflectors at three sites on the lunar surface. A fourth reflecting device is attached to a robotic lunar lander launched by the Soviet Union.
 
 To pin down the Moon's distance, scientists bounce light from Earth-based lasers off of these reflectors and measure how long it takes to return. Because the Moon's motion is governed by gravity, such studies can be used to test whether Einstein's general theory of relativity gives an accurate description of this motion.
 
 Some speculative theories of cosmology, such as one inspired by string theory that involves exotic particles called dilatons, predict deviations from general relativity.
 
 Other theories predict that the gravitational constant (G), which measures the basic strength of gravity, is not constant at all, but varies with time. These deviations are predicted to be very subtle, so more precise measurements are needed to either detect them or rule them out.
 So my question about if Lasers have proven the time distance from the big bang till now was very reasonable to anyone who had an actual clue about modern scientific techniques and theory. You are obviously a poser trying to pass for someone who has a clue, but in fact you only know what you have been told to believe. "Define"? As if it's a definition? Tell me, Archie: precisely how ignorant of this topic are you?

 
 WOW, and you call yourself a college educated teacher of science? And you don't even know that define means to describe? 
 
 
define |diˈfīn|
 verb [ trans. ]
 1 state or describe exactly the nature, scope, or meaning of : the contract will seek to define the client's obligations.
  give the meaning of (a word or phrase), esp. in a dictionary.
  make up or establish the character of : for some, the football team defines their identity.
 2 mark out the boundary or limits of : [as adj. ] ( defined) clearly defined boundaries.
  make clear the outline of; delineate : she defined her eyes by applying eyeshadow.
